thread.title: Detroit Lions takes offense that their plays are predictable
thread.title_full: Detroit Lions takes offense that their plays are predictable

author: freep.com
title: Detroit Lions takes offense that their plays are predictable
text:
MORE Now, this was predictable.
Two days after Golden Tate said in a radio interview that opposing defensive players were calling out their plays, the Detroit Lions said there's nothing too predictable about their offense.
"I don't think it's a problem at all," quarterback Matthew Stafford said. "I don't feel like (defenses know what we're running) very often at all, if ever, honestly."
Stafford threw two interceptions in a 24-12 loss to the Broncos last week when defensive backs Bradley Roby and David Bruton jumped routes out of their coverage area.
Roby and Bruton hinted that the Lions were tipping plays, and Tate said Tuesday that at least one opposing player has told him the same thing after every game this year.
DETROIT FREE PRESS
Lions' Tate: Comments weren't shots at Lombardi
But coach Jim Caldwell said Thursday that Tate's comments were "a little bit sensationalized" by the media and that teams generally have a good idea of what their opponents are running because of advanced film study and the audio available on game broadcasts.
Asked how often he knows what opponents are running, Caldwell said, "A lot more than what you'd think, let me put it that way."
"I think all teams study and work hard," Caldwell said. "There's always some tips here and there, but often what you find out is, much like from my days, I remember back in the old days when Bo (Schembechler) and Woody (Hayes) ran all of the same plays all the time. You knew they were coming, but the fact of the matter is, could you stop it? Because they could execute them so well. And I think that there's something to be said about that as well."
The Lions (0-3) rank 27th in the NFL in offense and are averaging 14 points per game over the past two weeks entering Monday night's showdown with the Seahawks (1-2).
They've struggled to run the ball, they haven't been able to pass protect, and they're tied for second in the league with eight turnovers.
"You study tendencies, you get a sense of tendencies," Caldwell said. "There's also audio nowadays where they're mic'ing your guards and centers and everybody hears your audibles. They hear different calls, they're going to pick up on something once in a while here and there. That kind of happens."
Stafford said his two interceptions last week came on plays the Lions had not run at any point this year.
Bruton told reporters in Denver on Monday that the Lions have a "high tendency of showing a particular play" and that he read Stafford's eyes after running back Ameer Abdullah chip-blocked a blitzer to make his game-clinching interception on a pass intended for Calvin Johnson in the fourth quarter.
"Legitimately, have not run that play, ever," Stafford said. "It was a specialty third-down play put in for their defense. Guy made a heck of a play. I give him a lot of credit. Physical play. It was a great one. Made a great tip. And heard that. Heard that he was reading my eyes, too. I was looking right and he was running left, he just got to his spot and made a good play. So it happens.
"Guys, when you win a football game, you can say what you want and I understand that."
DETROIT FREE PRESS
Lions' Caldwell: We're close, even if you can't see it
Lions safety Glover Quin said he might know what play an opposing offense is trying to run "about three or four times a game" thanks to good film study. Typically, he said players know another team's tendencies and can whittle down what they're trying to accomplish on a given play to a few general concepts.
"Nine times out of 10, why do backs chip?" Quin said. "Backs don't chip to run a quick slant, 'cause you don't even have to have an offensive line there to run a quick slant because the quarterback throws the ball so fast. Nine times out of 10, if a back chips, it's probably a deeper route because they're trying to buy time for protection. So if he chips, you automatically know, 'OK, it's a deeper route.' It's not like it's rocket science."
Seahawks coach Pete Carroll said in a teleconference with Detroit reporters that he hasn't seen any signs of the Lions giving away plays.
"I wish we could find the same things that they were talking about," Carroll said. "This is a tough team now, and they've got a lot of stuff they do. I don't see what they're talking about. It looks very difficult and challenging, definitely, in all phases."
Stafford said poor execution has been the biggest problem with the offense through three weeks, and he said everyone shares in the blame.
"We have way more options, I feel like, at our disposal on offense out of a certain formation than defenses do just from being sound-wise," Stafford said. "This is Football 202, and we're getting into some thought process stuff. But, yeah, for sure. It comes down to execution. It's been football for a long time and people run a lot of the same plays that they've always run, and it's just how you make them work."
